commentBody:
Well, exQQQQQQQQ me!

(Steve Martin did this puzzle decades ago.)

That was fast fun, with a pretty easy theme to grok and pretty easy clues.  I enjoyed the clue for a bejeweled egg knockoff ‚Äî FAUXBERG√â ‚Äî having viewed a big collection of them at the Metropolitan Art Museum in 1964.
In my defense, sometimes earrings do need to be rescued.
Very QT puzzle! Any more Qs and Qflation may befall us‚Ä¶
Qte.

Really fast and pretty easy to be quite honest.

A fun little jaunt, well executed.  I like more challenge on a Thursday but I'm not feeling up to pointless carping at the moment.

So I guess I'm reQQing myself.  :)
Even though it turned out to be easy, it was fun. Enjoy!

As a Canadian, who was born in Quebec, I have to say the "excuse my French" is just a bit offensive. Had the clue been "A non-PC comment after an oath", it might be OK. But seriously, is swearing (oaths) on a par with speaking French? 

Otherwise, this is very clever puzzle that I enjoyed. I don't want to appear thin-skinned here, just want to point this out...

This was a fine second Wednesday puzzle for the week.
Thanks, Joseph.

Now can we have a word with the editors?

Q the music. I enjoyed this puzzle and thought that FAUXBERGE was a SCARYGOOD entry. I originally tried daring deeds, but quickly spotted the Q theme thanks to ESQ, and got DARINGRESQQ.  After that, the puzzle fell into place steadily.

BRYN Mawr was a gimme, because it has a close relationship with my alma mater, and I took a lot of courses there.  It‚Äôs also where I met my first wife, and where I had my first job after graduation (managing the college snack bar).
J'accuse.

Loved ‚ÄúAppropriate inappropriately‚Äù‚Ä¶. thought it was code for a little hanky panky‚Ä¶ like‚Ä¶ wanna

Buy it is a long a in the first.  Nice!
Not enjoying the restyled update format.
Yeah, I thought eARRINGRESQQS were perfectly reasonable quests for gallant knights.

I‚Äôve mentioned before my love for the letter Q üòç I have a running list of puzzle ideas, and this one was on it!! Joseph did a phenomenal job with it (and for sure better than anything I could have put together). My husband is also an alum of Syracuse, so we both got a chuckle out of that one as it‚Äôs specifically on my list ü§£  I had one error when I finished. I had [Some queens] as BEeS üêù before BEDS. Thank you for the EXQQ to put off gift wrapping for a few minutes, Joseph. This was a fun jaunt.

I enjoyed this a lot. I found it harder, I think, than the other early commentators‚Äîmaybe because like Deb I had BEE before BED for ages and tried to fit USE in a rebus for SYRACUSE ORANGE even though I already had the two Qs in the first themer. Then it clicked, and it did get easier at that point, but I was still impressed‚Äîfirst for the relative smoothness of a difficult construction with all Qs, some SCARYGOOD accessory fill like FAUXBERGE and INNUENDOS and some fine cluing like EMANUEL and LIARS. So, a great all around puzzle for me.

I can't unsee MISDO.  "Waiter, there's a D in my soup!"

Fauxberges, though, that was pure gold (plated) !

Funny about plural endings: torsi and strata. Enoki.

Any of you have any nominations for the Griddies, please REPLY to this message. Each year volunteers have awarded prizes for the best puzzle of the year in 4 categories: M-W, Th, F-S, and Su. All are welcome to nominate as many puzzles as you wish. All we need is the name of the constructor(s) and the date of the puzzle (calendar year 2025). I'm doing it this year with Marshall Walthew and our fearless leader Eric Hougland. We do already have a lot of nominations, so I won't be making this...SPIEL again till after Xmas. Bring it on!

[Opinion piece by Zola?]
JAQQ
Not a difficult solve but odd that there's no clueing for the wordplay.
‚ÄúAlumni‚Äù‚Äîa gender-neutral designation using the plural masculine form?
I‚Äôve been enjoying the recent puzzles with lots of uncommon letters! Didn‚Äôt get the music at first. Did anyone else have REDS/ROASTS instead of BEDS/BOASTS?

I got tripped up by having bees instead of beds for a while but I was so proud of myself for figuring out the trick. I feel like I was staring at this for a while but then when I got it everything fell into place. Super satisfying solve.
How much is 2 Q's and 2 Q's?

29A gave away the Thursday madness rather quickly for me. Great to see my hometown the 'Cuse (QQ) represented,,,,GO ORANGE! still miffed why we chose a 'nothing to do with CNY' mascot in 1978 over the Saltine Warrior.  Perhaps inspired by all the FLA snowbirds?
Alas no solve today - too many misqq.

Sight unseen,  I can predict that:
-- MISDO at 43A will attract some attention, and rightfully so. Yeesh.
-- linguists and other fussbudgets (including me) will feel obliged to point out that, with all due respect to our esteemed blogger's alma mater, it doesn't fit the category. Syracuse, ending in an unvocalized S, cannot be transformed into double Qs, ending with a vocalized S or, in English, a Z.  BUS is not BUZZ, PACE is not PAYS, and SYRAkyoos is not SYRAkyooz.
A flaw in an otherwise charming puzzle.  And I share the fascination with what's difficult and really wanted the composer to succeed. The other QQs were perfect.
Oh how I tried rebi before the downs illuminated 57A!

I just awarded myself three stars: one for no look-ups, one for finishing it, and another one for finishing it. When the congratulations popped up I was stunned.  I should reQQ myself from judging my performance, but I thought it was pretty thrilling.

Joseph Gangi, I loved this‚Äîit was great fun!  Thank you.
I guess ‚ÄúThursday puzzle‚Äù is its own revealer now.  It‚Äôs all good, there‚Äôs really no XQQ for needing more.

J‚ÄôaQQ! I found this in one quite tough as I didn‚Äôt have the cultural context to infer the trick from 29A as other commenters seem to have. I ultimately clicked through a combination of 44A and 57A, but even then, took a while to get the whole thing out.

"Aren't you supposed to be on stage now talking about the 17th letter of the alphabet?"
"That's my Q!"

(They skipped over "Q"? Sounds like a PR stunt.)

i was in the middle of writing:

say, deb...
arent you an alumnA of syraqq?

and then i thought better of it and TIL that AN ALUMNI is accepted, though occasionally proscribed, for any individual of any gender.

there should be an expression for the combination of who knew?/dont like it.
Pretty good puzzle. 41A can be the cherry on top :)

Very nice midweek puzzle (depending on whether your week starts on Sunday or Monday). 

BRYN and BRETT were naticky but only because it‚Äôs been a while since the college has appeared here and an even longer time since I‚Äôve read Hemingway. 

SQFT is such an amusing unit. 

Thanks to the constructor and editors.
Is etiquette in the line for the loo minding your Qs and Ps?
Fun one!
XES OUT just looks gross and is never satisfying and should be banned from crosswordese. Not the worst Thursday by any stretch but also not the best
‚ÄúAlumni‚Äù is plural. A single graduate is an alumnus or an alumna. (Sorry, this is a pet peeve of mine.)

Sometimes you put letters down, reflect, and say "Yep, that's an English word" and hope for the best. 

Other days, your crossers deliver you an unequivocal QQ and, after a moment of disbelief, it all quickly comes together. 

Then later you see... BRYN. Yep, thats four letters in a row, I guess.
Proud of myself for solving this one, and was pleased to see my alma mater Bryn Mawr appear.

I really liked this puzzle.  It was elegant and clean with a nice theme (and 'aha') ... and some great misdirection clues which I grokked right away for the most part except  for 1A and 1D. I first had ROAST and REDS (ROAST is clearly wrong, what was I thinking, but some queens - in chess - are reds), then I had TOAST and TEDS and figured I just didn't know what a RED TED was ... then when I checked puzzle, and that square was wrong, I finally got BOAST and BEDS - forehead slap.

Thanks for pointing to the constructor's previous puzzles, I look forward to solving them.
Neat one! There were pretty tough words, but the reason It took me much longer than average is that "innuendo" isn't spelled with "E":)
I liked 41A...It CUE'd the QQ's!

Got the double qs with TOQUE and DQED and went ‚Äúhuh?‚Äù. Tried so hard to make it a rebus. Finally had to check with Deb. Found out I had it mostly right. I thought it was great. Thanks, Joseph! Happy Thursday, y‚Äôall!
Yay! Thanks Joseph.
Alumni is the new octopodes üêô

Love it! Fun theme, great Qs, lots of lines with multiple possibilities,

Can someone explain misdo? It wasn‚Äôt in my dictionary. Is it just miss do? 

‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

It took me longer than my average Thursday, thanks to BEES (not BEDS) and deleting QTR (for being next to another Q) and trying a couple rebuses. Finally, I had SYRA__ORANGE, then considered my previous deletions, and it dawned on me. To the constructor, I'm adding two more Qs to the ones in your puzzle, which makes 10Q. 10Q very much.

Though I enjoyed the puzzle today, a few things are bugging me. 

Surely a team is made out of more than the players on the court, no? I feel like this could have been worded better, a volleyball team usually has 12 players on the roster, at least by the CEV and FIVB rules. 

Also, Im not the biggest fan of using somewhat obscure TV actors' names to begin with so I had to look up 59D. I have seen Severance but don't even remember the character, how am I supposed to know the name of the actress?? This one was way too obscure imo.

Excellent puzzle but: QQ works for Syracuse and Unjustly Accuse - in both, the answer is a singular ‚Äúcuse‚Äù. But in ‚ÄúFeats performed on knights‚Äô quests‚Äù, the answer is plural: Daring Rescues. To be fair, it seems that the device should apply uniformly across the puzzle. Had a heckuva time with that.

I'm not sure what it says about me but the crossing of liquor and knights on quests brought the whole thing together for me, helping me figure out the theme pretty fast.

Fun puzzle, I thoroughly enjoyed. The NE corner required multiple look ups tho.
Today I learned the formal name for a chef's hat

BEeS/BEDS, another KEA/LOA.  Wait for those crosses...

Very impressive use of so many Q's.  Good job fitting in some nice longer non-Q fill like INNUENDOS, SCARY GOOD, and the new to me but now my favorite, FAUXBERGE.  

Fun, but Wednesdayesque, no?

Fun puzzle today, but that's a lot of QQ to still not add up to a pangram, eh?

Very clever theme, although for 44A I am much more accustomed to hearing PARDON than EXQQ.

I had an early inkling about 29A, suspecting that SYRAQQ was one of those schools that had resolved their sexism problem by referring to their teams simply as a blob of color. (REDMEN==>CARDINAL,q.v.)

After adjourning my city council meeting minutes before 11 last night, and getting up before 5:00 to take out the dog who didn't actually need to go out, I found this to be the appropriate level of challenge.

Thank you!

I sure sat here for quite a while wondering what earings have to do with knightly quests!
Fun puzzle, I really liked the QQ gimmick.

Well, I was Q‚Äôd to be charmed by this puzzle, because Joseph made what I consider to be the cutest grid art ever. I still smile thinking about it. To see it go here (spoiler alert, the grid will be filled in): https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/16/2022 . And even though there was no grid art today, I was charmed anyway, due to answers that brought delight ‚Äì SEGUE, RIFE, POMP, INNUENDOS, SCARY GOOD ‚Äì and clever opposite-based clues: [Off-line, online] for IRL, and [Appropriate, inaapropriately] for USURP. Much fun built into solving this ‚Äì grokking the theme and guessing at the theme answers with as few crosses as possible. Props to Joseph for coming up with this theme answer set, because there aren‚Äôt too many QQ‚Äôs words outside of resqqs, Syraqq, exqq, and aqq and their variants. Some others are reqq, barbeqq, pool qq, curliqq, and maybe qqticks. Are there more? Row 4 ‚Äì SIT EAT USURP doesn‚Äôt have the ring of EAT PRAY LOVE, but I still think t would make a great title. Your puzzle was charming, fun, and impressive, Joseph. Thank you for making it!
Wow. That's all I've got. Brilliant construction and clueing.
Very well done. Always a fan of the "a-ha!" moments.
I was amused by the q‚Äôs.
Would someone please explain why the clue for FAUXBERGE needed an e.g. after it, since it was specific to that particular item?
Aw man, I was so close to keeping my streak. tOAST wasn't it, neither was rOAST. Can't believe I didn't think of BOAST! Maybe I should drink my coffee before doing a  Thursday.

I'm amused that @Deb Amlen used the phrase "cruciverbal derring-do" in her column.  
When trying to solve the first themer at 17-A ("Feats performed on knights' quests"), I had DARIN----, and I thought to myself that the theme was going to involve common misspellings:  DARING for "derring", for example.
I was happy that I was mistaken.

It's nice to see the QQ getting attention, but I'm impressed that a puzzle focusing on that letter is able to include four X's, as well.

Nice, non-rebus Thursday.  Thanks, Joseph Gangi!
Go Orange!! üçäüçäüçä
Lived more than half my life in Japan, still haven't seen any ramen with ENOKI

Typical slow Thursday start for me, but tumbling to the trick was a huge turning point and that's always a nice touch. And, of course puzzle finds today. Some rather unusual ones. First - a Thursday from July 30, 2009 by Ashish Vengsarkar. Some clue/answer examples: "Facility" EEEE "Signals" QQQQ "Garden sights" BBBB "Man oh man!" GGGG And then two grid-spanning semi-reveal answers: FOURLETTERWORDS REPEATOFFENDERS Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/30/2009&g=8&d=A I'll put other puzzle finds in a reply (or replies). ...

Loved this puzzle.

Amused that the first word I put in (BEeS) was the last correction I needed to make

Loved all the xs and qs 
Lots of colorful ACC teams
Blue Devils, Yellow Jackets etc.
Also thought in terms of Carolina blue

TOTSI feels like a contortion but the Latin checks out

A very nice puzzle, but not really Thursday-esque. Barely took 15 minutes.

Got the theme with SYRAQQORANGE, though to me this is the one themer where the QQ substitution isn't quite right phonetically. 

Consider the infinitive "to USE" and the entry at 32A "OF USE". Different pronunciations of "USE" in each, at least for me. Same for me with "Syracuse"; the city in Central NY has the same sound as in "OF USE" and not that of "to USE". So QQ isn't quite right there, for my ears.

In any case, an enjoyable and clever puzzle. Liked FAUXBERGE, though it was completely unfamiliar.

Nice Scrabble score for this one!
Why are my comments not being accepted?
I really appreciate the art of getting this many painful letters into the grid.
I like to say Excuse my French whenever I attempt to say a French word or phrase since chances are I'm mispronouncing it.

Got the egg first and then kept trying to make that the trick everywhere. 

Agree it was a quick solve, but I'm about to take off to the hinterlands and need to rush. 

Check you guys later!
I don't usually comment on puzzles but once I cottoned on to the theme I really enjoyed this one. Hit me just right :) great work!

Quite difficult for me, and although I got some from crossers, I had to look up some in the end - from JD, SMOKEY, the Syracuse one, DOX, the lake, Trail Blazers, UNAGI, QTR, EBERT and the other names.

It wasn't the QQs that were the problem. But, some crosswords are like this for me, with unfamiliar words.

DCUSED? I can't get that one, nor the Taj Mahal clue.
Great one today.  Major head-scratcher - no, that doesn't fit - until MISIDENTIFY resolved itself.  That was the aha moment, and the rest was a delight.  More like this please.
LOVED this puzzle. Loved the clueing ...
Quite the Quick and Quirky Quandary today!

Had me going there for a bit as I had Qs rather than QQ. Overall, not too easy, not too hard for me. It cleared my morning cobwebs for sure.

Speaking of, my family called cobwebs Irish lace. Must be the German side. ;-) 

This Buffalo native had never heard that our fair lake was ever called Lac du Chat.

Half way through August 2013 in the crossword archive leaving just the rest of that year to complete the archive entirely. That‚Äôs 11,301 puzzles. Oy!

So good!!   The theme took a while but those are the best!

Had Queen BEeS for so long and just couldn‚Äôt understand eARINGRESQQ.   Then D‚Äôoh ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

Deb ‚Äî I always enjoy your columns.  Please keep them coming.  But you are an alumna of Syracuse, not the plural alumni.

Cheers,
Gerry Paul

I scampered through the NW corner thinking the puzzle would be too easy -- and once you have DARING RES with only two squares to go, QQ is easy.  It took me a bit longer than it should have to realize that all the trick squares would be a pair of Qs.  I loved EXQQ MY FRENCH and UNJUSTLY AQQ.

While I hate a great many of today's new coinages, I tend to love the clever portmanteaus.  Is FAUXBERGE great or what?

Puzzle hint for today:  All 5-letter film critics are EBERT -- just as all 4-letter critics are AGEE.  You're welcome.

Not the hardest Thursday, but colorful and enjoyable.

Note to either Deb or the headline writer (who may be a different person):  Today's "Q"-citing headline gives away the entire trick.  Which is fine if people who see it have already done the puzzle.  But what if the people scrolling by are on their way to Connections or Wordle???  Today's crossword will be ruined for them.  Please don't EVER give away the trick in the headline!  Thank you!

Today wasn't my favorite puzzle.  I didn't mind the QQs theme but I found the top right of the puzzle pretty impenetrable.

First, to DOX implies to call for people online to harass somebody online, it's not just to leak private info.  People talk about "Misdoings" but I've never once heard MISDO used as infinitive form.  And I'm not sure how somebody with no military experience would know a Platoon Sgt is an NCO.

That entire corner was Natick city for me.
Love the QQs.  I caught right on.  A good Thursday for me for once.

How fun!!  I started in the SE with (what else?) YER...and UNAGI (Thank you, Iron Chefs!)
I've just started reading _Things Fall Apart_...very apt.  

CAPRA for the movie quote?
Four letter lake?  MEAD?
Moving on to TH White and a short name for 'Granny'--doing better!  
  My thanks to DHubby for BUTANE instead of STERNO (yeah, yeah, I knew it was wrong, but ...desperation had set in.) 
Excellent FAUXBERGE after brief flirtation with FALSE/FAKE.

Then ...hmm EXQU?Y  (This can't possibly work!)
And then the sun breaks through, bluebirds sing, a rainbow appears!
This is just a wonderful puzzle and delightful solve.  I hadn't recalled earlier puzzles from Joseph Gangi, but I won't forget again.  (After all--good-looking AND clever?  What's not to like?)

I want to take this opportunity to say a huge THANK YOU to the fabulous, witty, and omniscient Deb Amlen, who leaves us way too soon to pursue her greater adventures in retirement.

You have been a constant and steadying voice to this beloved forum, and while I know your catchphrase is "It wasn't me!", I beg to differ:  it very much was you, and you will be greatly missed.
Thank QQ all around!

Best of everything to you, Deb! You will be sorely missed. I have enjoyed your column immensely and I credit you with my willingness to try Friday and Saturday puzzles. Yo you r humor has helped keep all of us a bit saner during these crazy times. THANK YOU! 

Also, fabulous puzzle today!

And... one more puzzle in the double letters area. A Sunday from August 5, 1984 by Vaughn Keith with the title: "All 26 doubled." And yep - it had answers that in total included a double of every letter in the alphabet. Some examples: CRABB APPOSITION OMARKHAYYAM FENNELSEED SLOGGERS SQQ (!) DIVVIES POWWOWS REDDFOXX CROSSEDOUT SALTCELLARS VACUUM OGEES FRIZZ BOOKKEEPERS RADII RAREE WITHHOLDING GNOCCHI ESSEX And there were more. Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=8/5/1984&g=70&d=A ....

I filled in DARING deeds. and prepared myself for another boring Thursday. Boy howdy, was I wrong! Enjoyed this one thoroughly.

I also loved FAUXBERGE, which was new to me but quite guessable. So I have to ask, is the watch in the column photo a FAUXLEX?

I figured out the IT'S, but the NE  was my undoing.  I'm scratching my head at 40 across.

This one was clever, but got the better of me.

@Deb

I'm so happy for you to be retiring, but so sad for us. However, being successfully retired myself, I offer my services if you haven't yet figured out your post-employed life! 

I keep saying I need to write a book on how to retire successfully, but the truth is, it probably isn't worth more than a newspaper column or magazine article. 

Regardless, thank you for your guidance these past years, as I went from Monday, Tuesday solver and hair-puller the rest of the week, to a confident weekly solver. You have had a positive impact on so many lives. I raise my coffee cup in salute and thanks! Le'chaim!

Started off with plenty of misQQ, including thinking the theme actually revolved around the letter X since there were a few Xes in the middle. Still I managed to get it done in 34 min with no help! Good puzzle, but not as brilliant as the first three this week.
Go Orange!
Great puzzle. I picked up on the cues and was able to do it in my normal Thursday time.

‚ÄúThere are a few more abbreviations than I normally like to see, and there are a couple of clues that slowed me down a bit because they just didn‚Äôt seem to hit the mark.‚Äù

Indeed.

A pleasant and smooth solve, ONCE I caught on.   A real feat of construction.  Well done.  

Later today I will be travelling to Uqqummiut (in Canada) and will watch Powaqqatsi along the way.
Loved this one!

I'm grateful to Deb for patiently teaching us to appreciate the complexity of a puzzle from the constructor's pov.  Still, appreciating someone else's achievement is not the same as actively grappling with a challenge yourself.  This was a cute theme and a breezy solve, but not much of a work-out.  I miss Tricky Thursdays of old.

I rather enjoyed this clever, FAUX twist today on seldom-used letters -- thank you, Joseph!

Happy Thursday, everyone!
I tapped out of this one too early. I should have made a couple of educated guesses in the NW corner because they were right. Oh well! What a clever puzzle!
If I've said it once, I've said it twice (üòÅ), puzzles like this are just mindbogglingly good. The fill is sublime and the clues are "chef's kiss*. Excellent job Joseph!
Great puzzle. A real workout and extra tricky. Challenging and a grand use of the letter Q. Thank you!

QQ me while I kiss the sky!

(Or, your variant of choice).  :)

I am a mid-morning solver (I'm not one of those late night weirdos; you know who you are...) and I have yet to read a single comment here, so I don't yet know the prevailing opinion of the puzzlistas.  But I'm just going to say it: I loved this puzzle.

When I got the first double Q at 17A I knew it was going to be a fun ride.  I got a LOL to boot (with FAUXBERGE, which I now know is actually a word, although I would have been fine with it otherwise).  I did pause at the volleyball clue, as I recently watched and re-watched a two-woman volleyball team do the impossible on YouTube, so I think the number of team members is fluid.  But, whatever.  And my years of living in Canada prepared me for TOQUE.

And if the 8 Qs weren't impressive enough, Mr. Gangi drops three Xs into his grid, irretrievably skewing the alphabet stats for the week.

Really a great puzzle.

It took me a little while to figure out the theme entries so I will REQQ myself from complaining‚Ä¶.

I really enjoyed this puzzle for its cleverness.

Good job. Fun in stages because amid partial fills, at first I thought I needed to sub in the rebus "CUE" for a "Q". I hadn't seen that there were plurals involved and a need for more Q's. 
Vanna, can I buy a consonant?
Vanna: "No." 
Delete rebuses, hope for a gold star.
@Deb - you are not "an alumni", unless the language has changed. That's a plural. But I certainly echo others in wishing you well in retirement.
I would have liked the puzzle more had there been a clever hint to the theme in one of the clues. Glad others enjoyed it.

This one took longer than average, which is rare these days. I've been doing this for about a year, and my early super long times skew my average, so it's not usually hard to beat. Like many others putting BEE for 1D set me back. The North in general was a challenge and it took me too long to get from knowing the theme had something to do with the "cues" parts of the words to realizing I needed to enter two Qs. 

The Syracuse entry was the easiest themer to get but also felt out of place since it was a very specific proper noun rather than a common phrase like the others.

"The Sun Also Rises" is one of my favorite novels, so it was nice to see it make an appearance. Hem's evocative "iceberg" style falls in the category of "often imitated, never duplicated."

@Deb, I've been doing the NY Times crossword since I was a teenager trying to beat my Dad and frequently explaining the cryptic clues to him. It was a fun game we'd play. We'd both solve the puzzle, and he'd come to me and complain about a clue. I'd explain why the clue was perfect and he'd get frustrated, especially after Will Shortz took over. I was used to Mr. Shortz and his wordplay, having been a long-time subscriber to Games Magazine. Yet, somehow, I only discovered your column recently. I appreciated looking at it everyday, especially for the harder puzzles to find out why an answer was what it was. Somehow, you almost always covered the ones that challenged me. All this to say, thank you and enjoy your well-deserved retirement! (Have they found your replacement yet? I'm available!)

Had to laugh at myself..31D, I confidently filled in "soso" and went about my business. Didn't notice until I was informed I was "so close". 
40 lashes! No "ex-qq-es" especially as I am a fan of the Orange!

My nationality obligates me to appreciate a good q(ueue), 'though no obligation was needed.
Extremely satisfying puzzle today. Thank you!
exqq me, this was a tough one.
New Thursday best for me! Really enjoyed this one!
It seems @Andrzej meant it.

I loved today's puzzle but I need to change the subject.

Did anyone else get a bit perturbed that the Year End Wrap Up for Games didn't include Crossword????

POETs, LIQUORS, INNUENDO, Kermit, and Severance... these are a few of my favorite things! When the NANA bites, when the UFOS sting, I simply remember my favorite things...

Anyhow, fun puzzle, fun theme, and fun fill, though quite fast for me. 

Also, like @Jacui J, I love an abundance of Qs (and Js).
I thought MISDO was a bit of a stretch.
This puzzle was a real Qtie!  Thanks Joseph!

2Qt for words! [Lac du Chat]=Lake ERIE was a gimme. The Erie tribe was known as the "Cat People." Why? Theories abound. Too bad we can't ask the Eries, but, as a people, they were extirpated by the Iroquois in an act of genocide. The Iroquois wanted better hunting grounds. The Lake Erie islands--Kelley's and the Bass Islands in Ohio, and Pelee in Ontario--were known as "les √éles aux Serpents," from the many watersnakes (Nerodia sipedon insularum) which made their homes there. Like the Eries, they were nearly extirpated, with a population of 1500 by 1999, when they were designated a "protective species," and, by 2009, their population had rebounded to 12 000. And trust me, the (human) islanders are still very protective of them! Here, for you, Mr. Gangi, is some Emmanuel Ax (with his wife Yoko Nozaki), apropos of little, save that the title contains a Q--I had this recording on vinyl when I was a teenager, and played it to death: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-3QkR6SuMLA&list=RD-3QkR6SuMLA&start_radio=1
Does this puzzle reQuire a high IQ to solve? Asking for a friend.

ooh!  ooh!

faux was a clue in the mini!
and it was fill in the maxi!
its a conspiracy!
its a synchronicity!
its just a plain felicity!!

(note to self:  get a life...)

CNY is Central New York.  I don't think Syracuse hates it.

The team name, originally Orangemen and Orangewomen, derive from the color of their uniform, which, as is common in New York, derives from the association with the House of Orange (no relation to the fruit), the Dutch royal family that colonized New Netherland, later New York.

The mascot, which is a fruit, derives from the team name.

The Saltine Warrior was a culturally insensitive former mascot of Syracuse University based on a real-life 16th century Onondaga warrior.

Yes, the inexplicable rebus trap.  

I went through it all.  When I found rebuses are possible, I started seeing them everywhere.  

I try to be rebus-resistant, meaning I need a couple two or three places that seem to need rebuses, and they need to connect logically with the theme as best I know it.

@AA

Here's a strategy for Thursdays:  Work the first two lines across, and then switch to the downs to get as much as you can of what you know will be a theme answer.  Then try to figure out the answer from the letters you have.

If you don't see anything at first, move on to the next similar area, and work around the theme answer until you have enough crosses to guess again.

Eventually, you'll see an answer that makes sense, even if it has something quirky in it.

In this puzzle, I saw ESQ and LIQUORS before I even took a look at 17A.  That told me something was up, and even if I didn't know exactly how it worked, it was fairly obvious that it was something other than a rebus.

Hope this helps!

@Frankie B
With you, Frankie. I work it out like this:
How many do you need to field at the game's start?  Assuming no injuries, is there anything in the game's rules that /requires/ any additional players? Can you complete the game with the same complement? Then, that's the number.
In baseball, even with the designated hitter rule, it's still nine. You /can/ use a designated hitter to hit for the pitcher,  you /can/ use pinch hitters and pinch runners, you /can/ use relievers and closers. But nothing requires you to. Start and end with the same 9 and you can complete a regulation game.
So 9 it is.
